name: apt39

procedures: T1003.001::[APT39] has used Mimikatz, Windows Credential Editor and ProcDump to dump credentials.
T1003::[APT39] has used different versions of Mimikatz to obtain credentials.
T1005::[APT39] has used various tools to steal files from the compromised host.
T1012::[APT39] has used various strains of malware to query the Registry.
T1018::[APT39] has used [NBTscan] and custom tools to discover remote systems.
T1021.001::[APT39] has been seen using RDP for lateral movement and persistence, in some cases employing the rdpwinst tool for mangement of multiple sessions.
T1021.002::[APT39] has used SMB for lateral movement.
T1021.004::[APT39] used secure shell (SSH) to move laterally among their targets.
T1027.002::[APT39] has packed tools with UPX, and has repacked a modified version of [Mimikatz] to thwart anti-virus detection.
T1027::[APT39] has used malware to drop encrypted CAB files.
T1033::[APT39] used [Remexi] to collect usernames from the system.
T1036.005::[APT39] has used malware disguised as Mozilla Firefox and a tool named mfevtpse.exe to proxy C2 communications, closely mimicking a legitimate McAfee file mfevtps.exe.
T1041::[APT39] has exfiltrated stolen victim data through C2 communications.
T1046::[APT39] has used [CrackMapExec] and a custom port scanner known as BLUETORCH for network scanning.
T1053.005::[APT39] has created scheduled tasks for persistence.
T1056.001::[APT39] has used tools for capturing keystrokes.
T1056::[APT39] has utilized tools to capture mouse movements.
T1059.001::[APT39] has used PowerShell to execute malicious code.
T1059.005::[APT39] has utilized malicious VBS scripts in malware.
T1059.006::[APT39] has used a command line utility and a network scanner written in python.
T1059::[APT39] has utilized AutoIt and custom scripts to perform internal reconnaissance.
T1070.004::[APT39] has used malware to delete files after they are deployed on a compromised host.
T1071.001::[APT39] has used HTTP in communications with C2.
T1071.004::[APT39] has used remote access tools that leverage DNS in communications with C2.
T1074.001::[APT39] has utilized tools to aggregate data prior to exfiltration.
T1078::[APT39] has used stolen credentials to compromise Outlook Web Access (OWA).
T1083::[APT39] has used tools with the ability to search for files on a compromised host.
T1090.001::[APT39] used custom tools to create SOCK5 and custom protocol proxies between infected hosts.
T1090.002::[APT39] has used various tools to proxy C2 communications.
T1102.002::[APT39] has communicated with C2 through files uploaded to and downloaded from DropBox.
T1105::[APT39] has downloaded tools to compromised hosts.
T1110::[APT39] has used Ncrack to reveal credentials.
T1113::[APT39] has used a screen capture utility to take screenshots on a compromised host.
T1115::[APT39] has used tools capable of stealing contents of the clipboard.
T1135::[APT39] has used the post exploitation tool [CrackMapExec] to enumerate network shares.
T1136.001::[APT39] has created accounts on multiple compromised hosts to perform actions within the network.
T1140::[APT39] has used malware to decrypt encrypted CAB files.
T1190::[APT39] has used SQL injection for initial compromise.
T1197::[APT39] has used the BITS protocol to exfiltrate stolen data from a compromised host.
T1204.001::[APT39] has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users to click on a malicious link.
T1204.002::[APT39] has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users to click on a malicious attachment.
T1505.003::[APT39] has installed ANTAK and ASPXSPY web shells.
T1546.010::[APT39] has used malware to set LoadAppInit_DLLs in the Registry key SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows in order to establish persistence.
T1547.001::[APT39] has maintained persistence using the startup folder.
T1547.009::[APT39] has modified LNK shortcuts.
T1553.006::[APT39] has used malware to turn off the RequireSigned feature which ensures only signed DLLs can be run on Windows.
T1555::[APT39] has used the Smartftp Password Decryptor tool to decrypt FTP passwords.
T1560.001::[APT39] has used WinRAR and 7-Zip to compress an archive stolen data.
T1566.001::[APT39] leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.
T1566.002::[APT39] leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious links to initially compromise victims.
T1569.002::[APT39] has used post-exploitation tools including RemCom and the Non-sucking Service Manager (NSSM) to execute processes.
T1588.002::[APT39] has modified and used customized versions of publicly-available tools like PLINK and [Mimikatz].

description: [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) is one of several names for cyber espionage activity conducted by the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS) through the front company Rana Intelligence Computing since at least 2014. [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has primarily targeted the travel, hospitality, academic, and telecommunications industries in Iran and across Asia, Africa, Europe, and North America to track individuals and entities considered to be a threat by the MOIS.(Citation: FireEye APT39 Jan 2019)(Citation: Symantec Chafer Dec 2015)(Citation: FBI FLASH APT39 September 2020)(Citation: Dept. of Treasury Iran Sanctions September 2020)(Citation: DOJ Iran Indictments September 2020)
